Risk Management – is a systematic process for anticipating things that may be dangerous, planning how to conduct an activity safely, and closely observing activities to be sure everything is going as planned.

 

•Identify what can cause harm

•Plan to minimise the harm that can be caused

•Supervise the entire activity and adjust safety plans to compensate for new conditions.

 

Safety precautions for handling lead pellets:

 

•Minimize the number of people who handle the pellets

•Make a handwashing station available after shooting

•Remind cadets to wash their hands with soap and water

 

 

 

 

Risk Management

Compare the risks and hazards (what can cause harm) to the mitigation strategy (how to minimise the harm) in the table below:

What can cause harm

Risks and hazards

Mitigation strategy

Eye injury from pellet ricocheting off target backstop

Ensure everyone at the firing point is wearing safety or prescription glasses

Person getting hit by a pellet because they didn’t know it was a range and walked past firing point

Put up barriers and signs around the range, and use a red flag to warn people that firing is taking place

Damaged equipment

Keep range area tidy and put equipment away after use

Participant accidently shoots person next to them

Ensure a handling test is completed by every participant before firing, and closely supervise all firing

Person trips and falls at firing point

Inspect range area before firing for trip hazards, and keep the firing point area clean and tidy during activities

Participant gets up to check their target before others have finished firing

Provide a detailed briefing before the activity, give range commands in a loud, clear voice, and closely supervise participants.

A participant notices a severe safety hazard while firing

Brief participants that anyone who notices a hazard can give the command “Cease fire!”

Lead is poisonous and can contribute to long term illness. A small amount of lead can be transferred to a person’s hands when pellets are handled. This lead can be safely washed away with soap and water.

Minimise the harm

 

RSO must take active steps to make the activity safer, for example:

 

•use safety equipment,

•restrict/block off access to the range for other people,

•follow policies, and

•check equipment for serviceability, etc.
